awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Large Ultrahigh-Vacuum Systems for Frontier Scientific Research Instrumentation
awd_abstract_narration:
Major new scientific instruments now planned for forefront research in physics and astronomy will require very large ultrahigh-vacuum facilities. In some areas, such as the next generation of laser interferometer gravitational wave observatories, the vacuum system is expected to form the dominant construction cost. Vacuum systems are also expected to be major cost drivers for advanced plasma fusion and particle accelerator concepts now under development. This workshop aims to compare vacuum needs of these future research facilities and to explore recent advances, new insights, and novel concepts that could render major cost savings in their realization. Doing so will help assure continued leadership in exploring our physical universe and in educating, enlightening and informing the public, with minimal future burden on public funds.  

LIGO Laboratory will host the workshop at the LIGO Livingston or LIGO Hanford observatory site in calendar 2019. Approximately 21 recognized vacuum experts will be invited to represent leading US and international research facilities and key supporting industries involved in applying large-scale vacuum system technology to fundamental research. They will join LIGO Laboratory faculty and staff for 3 working days with a mixture of presentations and panel-mediated discussions. Expected outcomes include the cross-pollination of technology paradigms between disparate fields and projects, and possible synthesis of entirely novel construction and fabrication concepts for future development.  Upon conclusion of the Workshop, the Organizing Committee will publish a publicly accessible  synopsis highlighting these findings and recommending directions for future pursuit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Workshop on Large Ultrahigh Vacuum Systems for Frontier Scientific Research Instrumentation was held at the LIGO Livingston, LA site on Jan. 28 - 31, 2019. The workshop primarily focused on the need to identify cost effective technologies for the design, construction and operation of the large vacuum systems that will be required for future gravitational wave observatories a factor of ten larger than current systems operating in the U.S. (LIGO), Europe (Virgo) and Japan (KAGRA).


The Workshop report effectively became a roadmap for the research program leading to vacuum designs for Einstein Telescope (ET) and Cosmic Explorer (CE), the proposed next generation of gravitational wave detectors. A core subgroup of participants representing CERN, LIGO, Jefferson Lab, NIST, Fermilab and College of William and Mary, along with LIGO consultants H.F. Dylla (American Institute of Physics) and D. Henkel (Material Forensics LLC), continued to meet online and undertook significant laboratory, modeling and commercial/industrial investigations at their respective institutions. A followup workshop, hosted by CERN in March of 2023, consolidated gains and became a springboard for large-scale demonstrations. In 2024 these received approval and took shape as the ET Pilot Sector Test, now underway at CERN in Geneva,  and the Cosmic Explorer Beamtube Experiment﻿ (NSF PHY-2422892), which started in August 2024 at LIGO Hanford.


Key findings coming from the Workshop and the collaborative research that it spawned include:

  • Verification of both mild (carbon) steel and ferritic stainless steels as extremely low-cost, hydrogen-free alternatives to traditional austinitic stainless steel for UHV beamtube application.
  • Novel degassing methods, including viscous flow scrubbing, can accelerate and/or reduce cost of large-scale bakeout for water vapor desorption.
  • Novel fabrication methods, including intermittent convolution and nested construction, can minimize duration and expense of extreme-scale tube production, installation and commissioning.

Alone or in combination, these and other developments promise to significantly reduce the cost, schedule and risk of CE and ET realization.

Award activity has also directly served the public interest. The compelling science enabled by next-generation gravitational wave interferometers will probe the densest matter in the Universe, trigger multi-messenger observations of binary systems, track black holes merging throughout cosmic time, illuminate the underlying nature of gravity, and map the life and death of massive stars. Like the LIGO discovery of gravitational waves, these revelations are destined to have a pervasive social impact, capturing imaginations and inspiring young people with the excitement and reward of evidence-based STEM inquiry. By applying industrial technology to Cosmic Explorer and other large-scale discovery machines, the Workshop program spawned new opportunities to attract future scientists, engineers, citizens and leaders.


The 2019 workshop at LLO also foreshadowed a second realm of synergistic impact. Lines of communication established between LIGO, Jefferson Laboratory, NIST, and CERN spawned a fluid, effective and durable fusion of practice and expertise from diverse fields of large-scale experimental physics.


Finally, the global objective of the Workshop, accelerating future large UHV projects and minimizing their  eventual cost to the taxpayer, fundamentally serves the public’s interest.


In summary, this award seeded an active and highly productive collaboration between multiple European, UK, Japanese and US groups. Significant research efforts for developing vacuum technology for Einstein Telescope and Cosmic Explorer were initiated and are now underway as a direct result of connections made in the Workshop.  The successful followup workshop at CERN in 2023 cemented gains and greatly expanded the effort. A third workshop in the series is now planned for May 2025, to be convened at LIGO Hanford.
